The intrinsic kinetics of CO methanation over the curved MoS2 catalyst were investigated in a fixed bed reactor. The activity was tested at Weight Hourly Space Velocity (WHSV) of 5000 mL g-1 h-1 and different temperatures from 627.15 K to 719.15 K, pressures from 2.6 to 3.4 MPa and H2/CO feed ratios from 0.5 to 2.0. The reaction kinetics model on the curved MoS2-N2 (001) basal plane was constructed by combining the LHHW and ER adsorption models, and Python was used to fit the model parameters based on the experimental results. Thirty-seven kinetic models were established and kinetic parameters were estimated using two nonlinear regression methods in Python software, resulting in the identification of the best-fitted model ( f = k p ( b H 2 P H 2 ) 1.5 ( b C O P C O ) 1.5 ( 1 + b C O P C O + ( b H 2 P H 2 ) 0.5 ) 2 ) and the activation energy of 72.343 kJ mol-1. This not only provides a method for constructing kinetic models in heterogeneous catalysis but also offers guidance for the design of reactors for CO sulfur-resistant methanation reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Intrinsic kinetics Sulfur-resistant methanation Mo-based catalyst MoS2 Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Energy plays a critical role in the maintenance and development of modern economies. In recent years, with the rapid development of the economy, energy demand has significantly increased. To address the energy crisis, the conversion from coal to synthetic natural gas (SNG) has been paid increasing attention worldwide in recent years. In the coal-to-SNG process, methanation from CO to CH4 is the essential step. Eq. (1) demonstrates the CO methanation reaction: (1) C O + 3 H 2 ⇌ C H 4 + H 2 O Typically, Ni-based catalysts have been widely used in the methanation process for their lower price and higher performance. Nevertheless, sulfur-containing gases are usually produced during the coal-to-CO process, leading to a quick poisoning and inactivation of the Ni-based catalysts. To overcome this, Mo-based catalysts have been developed for CO sulfide-resistant methanation reactions, which contain the active phase of MoS2 species [1]. Unlike Ni-based catalysts, hydrogen sulfide can exist in the methanation reaction of Mo-based catalysts and activate Mo species to maintain their active sites, contributing to improving the stability of the catalyst. As a consequence, Mo-based catalysts can eliminate the trouble of the fine desulfurization process and then remarkably decrease the cost [2]. Thus, developing high-performance Mo-based catalysts and studying reaction mechanisms have attracted much attention. Kinetic research plays a crucial role in studying the mechanism of catalytic reactions. By analyzing the rate at which reactants are converted to products in the catalyst's presence, we can infer details about the reaction pathway. This includes identifying intermediate species and determining rate-determining steps. Based on this information, we can develop various kinetic models to predict catalytic behavior under different conditions, which is essential for optimizing catalysts and scaling up sulfide-resistant methanation processes. The kinetics and mechanism of CO sulfide-resistant methanation over Mo-based catalysts have been investigated by many researchers, using empirical power functions. Hou et al. [3,4] investigated the kinetic model of CO methanation over MoS2/Al2O3 catalysts and found that the reaction rate is proportional to the first power of CO concentration and the 0.5 power of H2, respectively. Li et al. [5] constructed a macro-kinetic model for the CoO-MoO/CeO2-Al2O3-catalyzed CO methanation reaction, which eventually matched well with the experimental results. The study of the catalytic reaction kinetics model based on the law of mass action is essentially a study of the reaction mechanism. Therefore, it is inevitable to investigate the reaction mechanism to explore the reaction kinetics model. The investigation into the mechanism of CO sulfide-resistant methanation reactions constitutes a focal point in current research. Nevertheless, research regarding kinetic models for sulfide-resistant methanation remains relatively scarce, predominantly focusing on investigations using Density Functional Theory (DFT). Shi [6] confirmed the existence of the reaction intermediates (CHO1xy and CHO2xy) and the reaction process on the S-covered MoS2 (10–10) crystal plane by combining DFT calculations and DRIFT spectroscopy. This work identified a most likely reaction pathway in MoS2 (10–10) involving C1 surface species, as shown in Eq. (2). Li et al. [7] studied the CO methanation mechanism of MoS2 on (010) and (110) crystal planes through DFT simulations. Their results reveal that the S-edge sites of the (010) crystal plane and the corresponding reaction pathways on the (110) crystal plane are consistent with those identified by Shi, with the reaction pathway at the Mo-edge site presented in Eq. (3). In our previous work [8,9] DFT calculations were utilized to investigate the potential reaction pathways for CO methanation at traditional MoS2 edge sites (both Mo-edge and S-edge) and S-vacancies on the (001) facet. Concurrently, among the explored reaction pathways, the hydrogenation of CO to formyl species was identified as the rate-determining step. However, describing each specific catalyst's reaction pathway and rate-determining steps for different catalytic systems using DFT calculations demands considerable effort. Therefore, constructing a broadly applicable kinetic model can significantly alleviate the difficulty of exploring reaction pathways and rate-determining steps in complex systems. (2) C O + H → C H O + H → C H 2 O + H → C H 2 O H → C H 2 + H → C H 3 + H → C H 4 (3) C O + H → C H O + H → C H O H + H → C H 2 O H → C H 2 + H → C H 3 + H → C H 4 With the continuous evolution of machine learning, researchers have progressively extended its application into various disciplinary domains. For instance, in catalysis research, machine learning can aid in identifying and comprehending the mechanisms of catalytic reactions. By analyzing data from the reaction process, models can be established to infer potential reaction pathways and intermediate products. Utilizing machine learning for high-throughput data processing enables the derivation of more accurate model equations. Lustosa et al. [10] focused on how machine learning classifies mechanisms of catalytic reactions, discussing its potential in understanding and predicting catalytic process pathways, and highlighting its role in designing new reactions and improving existing ones. Elahe Anbari et al. [11] introduced support vector machines (SVMs) to predict product distribution in CO conversion reactions, validating the effectiveness with Co-Mo/Al2O3 catalysts. The results showed only a slight difference between the predicted data and experimental results, indicating the reliability of the SVMs method for CO conversion analysis. In summary, the reaction mechanism of Mo-based catalysts for sulfur-resistant methanation has not been fully established. To our knowledge, there is a significant gap concerning the kinetics of CO methanation on Mo-based catalysts, particularly about the unreported intrinsic kinetics of sulfur-resistant methanation over MoS2 catalysts. In this work, to compensate for this gap, we investigated the reaction kinetics on the activated S-vacancies of the curved MoS2-N2 (001) basal plane, which significantly enhances the CO methanation activity [9]. We constructed the kinetic model of the methanation reaction by combining the LHHW and ER adsorption models and employed Python to fit the model parameters to the experimental results. The best-fitted model was obtained, providing a foundational understanding of the reaction mechanism and kinetics of sulfur-resistant methanation on the Mo-based catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation In our previous work, we explored the effect of different degrees of bending in MoS2 slabs on the reaction activity and found that the MoS2 catalyst pyrolyzed under a N2 atmosphere had a larger number of S-vacancies, leading to improved catalytic performance. Accordingly, in this paper, we used MoS2-N2 as a model catalyst to test the experimental data of reaction kinetics. The MoS2-N2 catalyst was prepared by decomposing ammonium tetrathiomolybdate [ATM, (NH4)2MoS4] as the precursor, described in detail in Supporting Information. 2.2 Catalyst testing As shown in Fig. 1 , the catalysts were evaluated for sulfur-resistant methanation in a pressurized fixed-bed tubular reactor with a stainless-steel tube of 700 mm in length and 12 mm in diameter. The catalyst sample powder was pressed, crushed, and sieved to 20–40 mesh (0.43–0.85 mm), and 1.5 g catalyst was fixed in the middle of the reactor tube using 1.5 g quartz wool. After ensuring that the sealing was qualified, N2 was used as a protective gas to heat up to the vulcanization temperature at a rate of 10 K/min at normal pressure, and then switched to a mixture of 3% H2S/H2 for in-situ online vulcanization, maintaining the temperature until the end of the vulcanization process. Following vulcanization, N2 was fed again to heat the system to the experimental temperature at a rate of 10 K/min. To obtain more experimental data, CO sulfur-resistant methanation tests were performed under various conditions, within the range of T = 627.15–719.15 K, P = 2.6–3.4 MPa, H2/CO = 0.5–2.0, Weight Hourly Space Velocity (WHSV) = 5000 mL g-1 h-1. After stabilizing the reaction for one hour, the product streams were analyzed using gas chromatography (GC, SP3420A). Water in the product was condensed in a cold trap at −4 °C. Non-condensable gas products were desulfurized and dewatered in a detachment tank prior to on-line GC analysis. CO, CO2, and CH4 in the gas streams were separated on TDX-01 packed column and detected by thermal conductivity detector (TCD) using H2 as the carrier gas. Low-carbon hydrocarbons in the products were separated on a KB-Al2O3/Na2SO4 capillary column (50 m × 0.32 mm i.d.) and analyzed by a flame ionization detector (FID). The CO methanation conversion and the selectivity of CH4 were calculated based on the following equations: (4) X C O = F C O , i n − F C O , o u t F C O , i n × 100 % (5) S C H 4 = F C H 4 , o u t F C H 4 , o u t + F C 2 H 6 , o u t + F C 3 + , o u t × 100 % (6) S C 2 H 6 = F C 2 H 6 , o u t F C H 4 , o u t + F C 2 H 6 , o u t + F C 3 + , o u t × 100 % (7) S C 3 + = F C 3 + , o u t F C H 4 , o u t + F C 2 H 6 , o u t + F C 3 + , o u t × 100 % (8) C B = [ 1 − F C O , o u t + F C O 2 , o u t + F C H 4 , o u t + 2 F C 2 H 6 , o u t + 3 F C 3 + , o u t F C O , i n ] × 100 % where F represents the molar flow rate (mol min-1), i n represents the reactor feed, o u t represents the reactor discharge. C B mentioned above is the carbon balance during the methanation, the value of which is at the range of ±3%, which can guarantee the reliability of active test data. Where v 0 is the total volumetric flow rate (mL min-1), C C O is the concentration of CO in the feed flow, w c a t . is the weight (g) of the loaded MoS2-N2 catalyst during the reaction, x C O is the conversion of CO, − r C O is the reaction rate of CO. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Elimination of mass and heat transfer To ensure that the reaction remains within the kinetic control regime, it is required that the operational conditions guarantee the absence of mass and heat gradients in the reactor. This implies that the influence of internal and external diffusion, heat gradients, and pressure drop in the reactor have to be sufficiently eliminated. 3.1.1 Assessment of external diffusion Gas flow rate and catalyst morphology are important factors affecting external diffusion. Generally, adjustments to the feed space velocity and the catalyst particle size can modify these two factors. Specifically, the feed space velocity determines the external diffusion resistance, while the catalyst particle size determines the pore diffusion resistance. The Carberry number [12–14] has been introduced to assess the effect of external diffusion under various conditions of space velocity and particle diameters. Five types of catalyst particle sizes were selected: greater than 180 mesh, 180 to 140 mesh, 140 to 80 mesh, 80 to 40 mesh, and less than 40 mesh. The pore size distribution of MoS2 catalysts across these five different particle size ranges is depicted in Fig. 2 . As observed, catalysts across different particle sizes exhibit a consistent pore size distribution, primarily concentrated around 4 nm. This consistency ensures that the variations in activity data can be attributed to differences in pore size. When WHSV is reduced to the point where the influx of reactant molecules per unit time falls below a certain threshold, the reaction rate becomes dependent on the diffusion rate. Conversely, an increase in WHSV (i.e., the influx of reactant molecules per unit time) can effectively raise the turnover frequency (TOF), assuming the active sites are not saturated. Yet, as WHSV continues to rise to a point where the demand for active sites significantly undermatches the number of reactant molecules, the CO conversion rate declines due to shorter residence times on the catalyst's active sites. The results depicted in Fig. 3 show a decreasing trend in the CO conversion rate with WHSV increasing from 2000 mL g-1 h-1 to 9000 mL g-1 h-1, indicating that a space velocity above 2000 mL g-1 h-1 can provide sufficient reactant concentration to fully exposes the role of catalyst's active sites. To evaluate the effect of space velocity on external diffusion, the Carberry number has been calculated, defined as the ratio of the apparent rate ( r o b s ) to the maximum mass transfer rate ( r m a x , i ): (13) C a g s = r o b s r m a x , i = r o b s k g A s ( C i * − C i 0 ) Note that the effect of external diffusion is negligible when the Carberry number is less than 0.05 [12,14,15]. Calculations of the other parameters in the formula are detailed in Supporting Information. The Carberry number of CO on the MoS2 catalyst was calculated from Table 1 . When the WHSV reached 4000 mL g-1 h-1, the corresponding Carberry number was found to be less than 0.05, indicating that the influence of external diffusion on the reaction is negligible. Since we generally use a space velocity of 5000 mL g-1 h-1 for sulfur-resistant methanation, and this space velocity meets the requirement for eliminating external diffusion, we will use a space velocity of 5000 mL g-1 h-1 in the subsequent tests. 3.1.2 Assessment of internal diffusion There are numerous factors affecting the internal diffusion in gas-solid heterogeneous catalysts. To enhance the catalytic performance, the impact of internal diffusion can be reduced by optimizing the pore structure, morphology, and distribution of the catalyst. According to Chapter 1, the MoS2-N2 catalyst was used as the model catalyst in this work, noting that the pore size distribution among the catalysts of different particle sizes was comparably similar. Considering the factors influencing internal diffusion, catalysts of varying particle sizes were selected to evaluate and eliminate the effects of internal diffusion. In order to assess the effect of internal diffusion on the catalyst's performance, the Wheeler-Weisz number (ηφ2) was introduced [14–18]. When ηφ2 is less than 0.1, the influence of internal diffusion can be ignored. As ηφ2 increases, the effect of internal diffusion becomes progressively more significant [19,20]. The calculation is as follows, and details of the other parameters in the formula are given in Supporting Information: (14) η φ 2 = r o b s R 2 D e f f , i C i * The Wheeler-Weisz numbers were calculated for different particle sizes, ensuring the same pore sizes, with results presented in Table 2 . It can be concluded that as the mesh number of catalyst particles increases, which also means the particle size decreases, the Wheeler-Weisz number gradually decreases. For mesh numbers greater than 180, the Wheeler-Weisz number falls below 0.1, suggesting that the particle size's effect on internal diffusion becomes negligible. In summary, to eliminate the influence of internal and external diffusion, the Carberry number and Wheeler-Weisz number were employed to evaluate the influence by altering the feed space velocity and catalyst particle size. These results suggest that the influence of internal and external diffusion can be neglected when the feed space velocity is 5000 mL g-1 h-1 and the particle size is above 180 mesh. 3.1.3 Assessment of heat transfer To obtain a reliable kinetic expression, it is essential to ensure the data are isothermal. This necessitates meeting the following conditions: maintaining minimal radial and axial temperature gradients, avoiding any heat transfer limitations at the interphase or within particles, and keeping the pressure drop across the catalytic bed low [21–23]. Several criteria to assess the influence of heat transfer are comprehensively described in the Supporting Information. Based on the best-fitted kinetic model derived from the experimental data in the following sections, all the criteria outlined in Table S4 were fulfilled. Consequently, all the rate and selectivity data presented in this study are assumed to accurately represent the intrinsic catalytic processes involved in the sulfur-resistant methanation over MoS2 catalysts. 3.2 Kinetic study 3.2.1 Experimental results To provide robust reaction evaluation data for the subsequent kinetic model selection process and to fit the data for different models, the sulfur-resistant methanation experiments were carried out using MoS2-N2 catalysts with a particle size of less than 180 mesh, under conditions of T = 627.15∼719.15 K, P = 2.6∼3.4 MPa, H2/CO feed ratio = 0.5∼2.0 and WHSV = 5000 mL g-1 h-1. Each set of data was evaluated by reloading with the fresh catalyst to ensure the reproducibility of the experimental data. The reaction results are summarized in Table 3 . As shown in Table 3, the conversion rate of CO significantly changes with the H2/CO ratio, demonstrating that the conversion rate is correlated with the reactants’ partial pressure, i.e., there is a non-zero power positive correlation between the reaction rate of CO and the partial pressures of CO and H2 according to the Law of Mass Action. Furthermore, the reaction rate of CO markedly increases when the partial pressure of H2 exceeds that of CO. This not only indirectly verifies the hydrogen-assisted dissociation process mentioned in Chapter 1, but also suggests that the influence of H2's partial pressure on the reaction rate is at least as significant as that of CO. These findings also provide valuable guidance for constructing the subsequent kinetic model. 3.2.2 Reaction rate equation 3.2.2.1 Kinetic model adaptation discussion The core challenge in the kinetic study of heterogeneous catalytic reactions is to construct a suitable reaction rate equation. The heterogeneous catalytic process includes complex phenomena such as adsorption, surface reaction, and desorption, making the derivation of an overall reaction rate equation from individual reaction steps very difficult. To address this complexity, two widely used simplifications are employed: the steady-state approximation and the rate-determining step. Therefore, the dynamic expression of the experimental data can be modeled by the following two models. The LHHW model is a diffusible-reaction catalytic reaction model, which considers the temperature, component distribution, and the diffusion of reactants inside the catalyst particle. The basic assumption of the model is that the reactions inside the catalyst particle take place in partial equilibrium. Initially, reactant molecules adsorb on the surface of the catalyst particle and then diffuse deeper into the particle to react. In the LHHW model, typically, the reaction rate inside the catalyst particle is described by the Arrhenius equation. Mirzaei et al. [24] applied the LHHW model to the Fe-Co-Ni catalyzed Fischer-Tropsch (F-T) reaction and obtained 18 different models. A suitable kinetic rate expression was finally fitted by the experimental data. Subsequently, Mirzaei [25] obtained a kinetic rate expression for the Fe-Co-Mg-catalyzed F-T reaction using the same method. Therefore, the LHHW model provides a method for constructing a kinetic model of the F-T reaction. The ER model describes the adsorption and reaction of gas molecules on solid surfaces. According to this model, molecular adsorption requires an additional adsorption site that enables the gas molecule to react with the reactants already adsorbed on the surface. This requirement distinguishes it from the LHHW model, where all reactants must be adsorbed at the same positions. This process involves two steps: gas molecules first adsorb to unoccupied sites, then react with molecules already adsorbed on the surface. This mechanism is usually suitable for fast surface adsorption reactions, such as redox reactions with catalysts. A comparison of the two models shows that the ER model has the advantage of being able to describe reactions that do not fit the LHHW model's assumptions, such as low surface activity or difficult reactant adsorption. However, the ER model requires detailed knowledge of reactant activity, which is usually difficult to measure or estimate. Additionally, the ER model assumes that gas-phase reactants can directly react with the reactants adsorbed on the surface, but in practice, gas-phase reactants often need adsorption onto the surface before engaging in reaction, which requires the LHHW model. Given that the two models correspond to different aspects of heterogeneous catalytic processes, the model construction will involve selecting between the two models based on specific situations to ensure the model's universality and applicability. 3.2.2.2 Construction of the kinetic model Based on the two different mechanism models mentioned in the previous section, different elementary steps of the methanation reaction can be disassembled. It should be noted that the LHHW model usually assumes that the reaction is irreversible. This is because the main application of the LHHW model is the reaction inside catalyst particles, where conditions of high temperature and pressure prevail. Under such extreme conditions, reactions tend to reach equilibrium slowly and are therefore considered to be quasi-irreversible. Conversely, the ER model typically does not account for the desorption of products, operating under the assumption that gaseous reactants initially meet and react with adsorption sites on the catalyst surface in the gas phase. Then, the products will leave the catalyst surface directly without desorption. The ER model is therefore suitable for situations where the reaction rate is limited by the transfer of gaseous reactants in the gas phase, such as when the diffusion rate of gaseous reactants over the catalyst particle surface is notably slow. Consequently, in developing the elementary reaction rate equations for the rate-determining step, the effect of reverse reactions on the reaction rate is not considered. Considering the hydrogen-assisted dissociation or direct dissociation hydrogenation process involved in CO methanation, the reaction is divided into 17 possible situations according to different possible intermediate products, as detailed in Table 4 . To derive each LHHW and ER kinetic model, the rate-determining steps were first determined, while other elementary steps were assumed to be at equilibrium. This approach yielded thirty-seven rate equations based on the different rate-determining steps, as shown in Table 5 . As an example, the derivation of rate equations is illustrated by the model Ⅱ, which identifies C O S + H 2 ⇌ C H 2 O S as the rate-determining step, allowing the corresponding rate equation to be expressed as follows: (15) − r = k p P H 2 θ C O S where S stands for the adsorption site, and θ C O S is the surface fraction occupied with the adsorbed CO. The selection of the appropriate kinetic model was based on the effectiveness of the fit. However, the constructed kinetic model encompasses many kinetic parameters, and the limitation of experimental data impedes the accuracy of parameter fitting. On account of this, parameter fitting was carried out using an appropriate nonlinear regression method in Python. This not only simplifies the huge data fitting process but also increases the feasibility and reliability of the fits. For such complex nonlinear equations, as shown in Table 5, the nonlinear least square method (Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm) is typically employed for parameter fitting. In Python, the SciPy library provides two functions for nonlinear regression, called curve-fit and leastsq. Curve-fit is mainly designed for nonlinear regression problems with constraints, whereas leastsq addresses unconstrained nonlinear regression problems. Given the physical significance of the parameters in models, the regression problem transforms from unconstrained to constrained. Consequently, relying only on the leastsq function may not yield the most suitable kinetic parameters. Therefore, two different regression approaches were used in this section: A, utilizing the curve-fit function to regress the model with constraints; B, employing curve-fit for initial regression, followed by leastsq function with the curve-fit results as initial values to regress the model. Both methods were evaluated by cross-validation, with the specific regression method detailed in Supporting Information. It is noteworthy that cross-validation, a machine learning technique, serves as an effective means to evaluate and select models, particularly in solving over-fitting or under-fitting issues arising from limited experimental data in the fitting process. This method evaluates the model performance more comprehensively by dividing the dataset into multiple subsets for training and testing. Among all cross-validation methods, the most commonly used is K-fold cross-validation. The dataset is divided into K subsets, each subset is alternately used as the test set, with the remaining subset serving as the training set. This cycle repeats K times, and the average of the evaluation results is the final result. This method not only minimizes the effect of inappropriate data partitioning but also makes full use of the entire dataset to enhance the model's universality. Table 5 reveals that leastsq method, an unconstrained nonlinear regression technique, tends to significantly deviate from the expected parameter ranges during model fitting. Therefore, leastsq has its inadequacy for obtaining valid fits, thus necessitating the use of the curve-fit method. Optimal results were initially assessed using the R2 (A) value for all experimental data. However, due to the limitations of the experimental results, cross-validation was added as an additional critical indicator for model parameter fit. Here, RMSE (A) represents the root mean square error obtained by a single nonlinear regression method, while RMSE (B) denotes the root mean square error after multiple cross-validation. This index can better reflect the model's fit to experimental data under different conditions. Furthermore, the statistical robustness of the kinetic models was evaluated using the F-test, a critical tool in the analysis of variance (ANOVA) for determining the significance of regression models in chemical kinetics. The F-value is calculated as the ratio of the mean regression sum of squares (MSR) to the mean residual sum of squares (MSE), as detailed in Section S4 in the Supporting Information. A key criterion for statistical significance is that the computed F-value must exceed the critical value derived from the theoretical F-distribution for the corresponding degrees of freedom. Considering the overall context, the lowest RMSE (B) obtained by cross-validation, the R2 (A) closest to 1 from single fitting, and a higher F-value were chosen as comprehensive evaluation indexes to determine the optimal dynamic model. Among all models, Model 27 exhibited the best fit, as indicated in Table 6 , which includes parameters such as the reaction rate constant k 0 , the activation energy Ea, adsorption rate constants for CO and H2 ( b C O , 0 and b H 2 , 0 ), the single fitting correlation coefficient R2, the root mean square error RMSE, and the F-value. Fig. 4 shows the comparison between the calculated and experimental CO conversion rates for Model 27, demonstrating a high degree of agreement that reflects the model's adaptability. Meanwhile, for the fitting of kinetic model parameters with limited experimental data, the confidence interval for both experimental data and model calculation data is determined by the significance level α. Due to the small number of samples selected for this study, α is set at 0.15, leading to a confidence interval of [85%, 115%], as indicated in Formula (25). The range of the confidence interval is marked within the range of the orange dotted line in Fig. 4. (25) C o n f i d e n c e i n t e r v a l = [ ( 1 − α ) × 100 % , ( 1 + α ) × 100 % ] Unlike the common perspective that MoS2 catalysts have active sites at the S-edge and Mo-edge on the (010) crystal plane, we propose that the curvature of MoS2 creates a certain number of S vacancies on its inert (001) crystal plane, which then act as active sites for the reaction. According to the previous work [9] on DFT calculations regarding the methanation mechanism of MoS2, the reaction pathways of MoS2 (010) edge sites (both S-edge and Mo-edge) and S vacancies on the (001) basal plane are demonstrated in Fig. 5 . It is observed that the elementary reaction pathway for Model 27 is highly consistent with the pathways on S vacancies obtained by DFT calculations. That is, the CO methanation reaction on the MoS2-N2 catalyst generates a CHO* intermediate through the CO hydrogen-assisted dissociation, followed by further hydrogenation through CHOH*, CH2OH*, and CH2* intermediates, and finally generates the target product CH4. Besides, the rate-determining step for Model 27, as well as for the pathways derived from DFT calculations, is identified as CO hydrogenation. The matching of the model, DFT simulations, and experimental data not only proves the model's reasonableness but also confirms the reliability of the DFT calculations. The rate equation of Model 27 reveals that if the numerator and denominator are regarded as the driving and resistance terms of the reaction, respectively, the driving term approximates a cubic value, while the resistance term approximates a quadratic value. Consequently, the reaction rate increases with the partial pressures of CO and H2, suggesting that pressurization promotes sulfur-resistant methanation. This conclusion is supported by experimental data showing that the reaction rate increases with overall pressure. Furthermore, although the driving terms are expressed as the 1.5th power of the partial pressures of H2 and CO, it is important to note that bH2 is significantly greater than bCO. This results in a more pronounced effect of changes in H2 partial pressure on the reaction rate, which is also confirmed by experimental data indicating that, under the same total pressure, the reaction rate increases with a higher H2/CO ratio. In the CO methanation reaction, it is observed that producing 1 mole of methane from 1 mole of CO requires at least 3 moles of H2. However, MoS2 exhibits high activity for the reverse water-gas shift reaction, allowing for the rapid replenishment of the H2 required for CO hydrogenation. Additionally, the equilibrium of the reverse water-gas shift reaction on MoS2 is reached swiftly, meaning it is not the rate-determining step. As a result, this is reflected in the model by the difference in the values of bCO and bH2, rather than by a difference in the exponents of the partial pressures of CO and H2. In other words, increasing the H2 partial pressure does not significantly improve the sulfur-resistant methanation efficiency of MoS2 catalysts. 4 Conclusion In this study, comprehensive kinetic experiments for the CO methanation reaction were performed using the curved MoS2-N2 catalyst under a range of operating conditions in a pressurized fixed-bed reactor. Based on Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hogan-Watson and Eley-Rideal adsorption theories in catalytic processes, we constructed thirty-seven different kinetic models for CO methanation, integrating all possible reaction pathways. Using two nonlinear regression methods and cross-validation in machine learning, the model f = k p ( b H 2 P H 2 ) 1.5 ( b C O P C O ) 1.5 ( 1 + b C O P C O + ( b H 2 P H 2 ) 0.5 ) 2 was chosen as the optimal kinetic model. This model showed that the CO methanation reaction involves the hydrogen-assisted dissociation of CO to produce the CHO* intermediate, followed by further hydrogenation of the CHOH* and CH2* intermediates to produce the target product CH4. The kinetic parameters were obtained, revealing an activation energy of 72.3 kJ mol-1 for this model. coredata.dc:description: The intrinsic kinetics of CO methanation over the curved MoS2 catalyst were investigated in a fixed bed reactor. The activity was tested at Weight Hourly Space Velocity (WHSV) of 5000 mL g-1 h-1 and different temperatures from 627.15 K to 719.15 K, pressures from 2.6 to 3.4 MPa and H2/CO feed ratios from 0.5 to 2.0. The reaction kinetics model on the curved MoS2-N2 (001) basal plane was constructed by combining the LHHW and ER adsorption models, and Python was used to fit the model parameters based on the experimental results. Thirty-seven kinetic models were established and kinetic parameters were estimated using two nonlinear regression methods in Python software, resulting in the identification of the best-fitted model ( f = k p ( b H 2 P H 2 ) 1.5 ( b C O P C O ) 1.5 ( 1 + b C O P C O + ( b H 2 P H 2 ) 0.5 ) 2 ) and the activation energy of 72.343 kJ mol-1. This not only provides a method for constructing kinetic models in heterogeneous catalysis but also offers guidance for the design of reactors for CO sulfur-resistant methanation reaction.
